text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The behaviour of the Greek and Turkish Cypriot sides in the Cyprus dispute are coming under the scrutiny of the European Union.
- Swiss media pokes fun at Cyprus Airways pilots, one of whom last week landed a planeload of Swiss tourists at the wrong airport because he did not want to work overtime.

- An Armenian woman who went to a police station to collect her missing son was arrested as an illegal immigrant. Attorney-general orders an inquiry into deportation action against the woman, under United Nations protection.
- President Glafcos Clerides leaves hospital after heart tests.
- Former bosses of Cyprus Airways have started blaming one another for the airline's demise.
- Laiki Factors claims a 49 percent local market share.
- Protectionism policies towards Cypriot businesses has an expiry date, Communications and Works Minister Leondios Ierodiakonou tells parliament.

- Police used batons and teargas to disperse students of the Higher Technical Institute on a protest march to the Labour Ministry. The students want a legislation framework for the operation of the institute.

- International mediators on the Cyprus dispute have still not extracted a "yes" out of Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash for a give and take procedure during upcoming talks on the basic elements of the problem.
- Denktash rejects compromise on basic aspects of the Cyprus dispute such as sovereignty, the guarantor system and issues of security.
